response: Education in schools about probability and house edge. Kids need to understand the maths before they're exposed to betting.
Mandatory warnings like on cigarette packets. Every gambling ad should show addiction statistics prominently.
Fund public information campaigns using gambling tax revenue. Show the real consequences of addiction.
Time delays on bet placement. Make people wait 24 hours before bets are active to prevent impulsive gambling.
Replace gambling ads with mental health support ads. Use the same time slots to promote help services.
Create a national self-exclusion database that works across all platforms and is properly enforced.
Limit advertising to gambling company names only, no odds, no offers, no encouragement to bet.
Use technology to identify problem gambling patterns and intervene before it's too late.
Government-run information service providing unbiased facts about gambling risks and probability.
Require all gambling companies to contribute to a treatment fund proportional to their advertising spend.
Pop-up warnings during online betting showing how much you've lost in real time.
Partner with sports stars to deliver anti-gambling messages with the same prominence as betting ads.
Make gambling companies show their profit margins transparently. People need to know the house always wins.
Cooling-off periods between bets. No instant re-betting to chase losses.
Ban credit card gambling entirely. If you can't afford to lose it, you shouldn't bet it.
Mandatory reality checks every 30 minutes showing time and money spent.
Support groups advertised in betting shops and on gambling sites, funded by the industry.
Age verification that actually works. Too easy for kids to gamble online currently.
Financial education in schools specifically covering gambling, debt, and addiction risks.
Limit maximum bets for under-25s. Young people are most vulnerable to addiction.
Gambling company staff trained to spot problem gambling and required to intervene.
Public health campaigns showing gambling addiction as seriously as drug addiction.
Ban all inducements - no free bets, no deposit matches, no loyalty schemes.
Require proof of income for accounts. Prevent people betting beyond their means.
Default deposit limits on all accounts that require active steps to increase.
Graphic warnings on betting slips like cigarette packets - show the damage gambling causes.
Independent regulator with real teeth, not industry self-regulation that clearly doesn't work.
Link gambling accounts to credit records. Make visible the financial damage in real time.
Community education programs in areas with high gambling problems. Target the most vulnerable.
Ban VIP programs completely. They target and exploit problem gamblers specifically.
Require annual health checks for regular gamblers, like MOTs for cars.
Clear labeling of odds in plain English. Most people don't understand probability properly.
Addiction recovery stories given equal airtime to gambling ads. Show both sides.
Maximum loss limits enforced across all platforms. No one should lose their home to gambling.
Family notification systems - let loved ones know when gambling becomes problematic.
Ban algorithmic targeting of vulnerable users. No personalised offers based on losses.
Require gambling companies to call customers who show problem patterns, not just email.
NHS gambling clinics in every major town, funded by industry levy.
Make self-exclusion permanent and irreversible. No way back once you've acknowledged a problem.
Slow down betting systems. No instant gratification that feeds addiction.
Transparent reporting of problem gambling statistics by all operators. Name and shame the worst.
Life skills education including understanding risk, probability, and addiction psychology.
Ban gambling apps from phones. Make it harder to bet impulsively.
Require in-person registration for gambling accounts. Online anonymity enables addiction.
Gambling addiction officers in job centers and debt advice services. Catch problems early.
Make gambling debts non-enforceable in court. Remove the fear factor that drives desperation.
AI monitoring of betting patterns with mandatory intervention for at-risk behaviors.
Replace exciting gambling ads with boring, factual information about odds and risks.
Mandatory contribution to research on gambling addiction from every bet placed.
Support for families of problem gamblers, not just the gamblers themselves.
License gambling like driving - prove you understand the risks before you can bet.
Public registers of problem gamblers (with consent) to help them maintain abstinence.
Gamification in reverse - make saving money as exciting as gambling through apps.
Mandatory breaks in play. Force people to step away and think.
Financial advisors in betting shops to offer alternative investment advice.
Track gambling losses on credit reports so lenders can see the full picture.
Community support groups in every area, like AA but for gambling addiction.
Ban gambling companies from sponsoring anything aimed at under-25s.
Make treatment free and immediate. Current waiting lists are shameful.
Positive role models speaking about choosing not to gamble, especially in sports.
Require annual license renewal for gambling with mandatory education updates.
Link bank accounts to gambling controls. Banks should protect vulnerable customers.
School programs where recovered addicts share their stories with students.
National helpline advertised as prominently as gambling companies advertise.
Remove gambling from sports venues entirely. No betting kiosks at stadiums.
Mandatory podcasts about gambling harm for anyone opening a betting account.
Tax gambling winnings heavily to discourage the dream of getting rich quick.
Require employers to offer gambling addiction support like they do for other health issues.
Create alternative entertainment in communities - boredom drives gambling.
Mandatory saving accounts linked to gambling accounts - save as much as you bet.
Public health warnings at point of bet, not just in small print no one reads.
Train bar staff to recognize problem gambling in venue betting terminals.
National curriculum must include gambling awareness from primary school age.
Create shame-free zones for admitting gambling problems and seeking help.
Use recovered addicts as counselors - lived experience is powerful.
Make gambling companies pay for the police time dealing with gambling-related crime.
Smartwatch apps that detect stress and block gambling apps during vulnerable moments.
Replace gambling sponsorship with health and wellbeing company partnerships.
Let people set their own limits but make them legally binding on operators.
Mandatory mental health assessments for anyone betting over certain thresholds.
Create positive addictions - sports, hobbies, community work - as alternatives.
Full transparency on where gambling tax revenue goes - show the social benefit.
Peer support networks in workplaces to spot and support struggling colleagues.
Make gambling boring. Remove all the excitement and glamour from marketing.
Financial products that make saving as emotionally rewarding as gambling.
Mandatory annual reports from gambling companies on harm reduction efforts.
GPS blocks on gambling apps near schools and youth centers.
Recovering addicts employed by gambling commission as inspectors and advisors.
Make problem gambling a factor in child custody cases - protect families.
University courses for addiction counselors specifically focused on gambling.
Corporate responsibility programs where businesses support employees with gambling issues.
National database of gambling harm stories - make the consequences visible.
Require gambling operators to visit addiction centers monthly to see the damage.
Technology solutions - apps that block all gambling sites and can't be overridden.
Make gambling addiction treatment a right, not a privilege for those who can afford it.
Regular public inquiries into gambling harm to maintain pressure for change.
Support research into why some people are vulnerable to gambling addiction.
Create competing activities that provide similar thrills without financial risk.
Early intervention in schools when children show signs of risk-taking behavior.
Make hope more accessible than gambling - address the desperation that drives it.
